contentrichtext.text: '''Albert F. Sabo''' (December 21, 1920 â€“ May 8, 2002) was an [[American law]]yer and [[judge]] of the [[Philadelphia County, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia County]] [[Pennsylvania Courts of Common Pleas|Court of Common Pleas]]. He is best known for presiding over the [[Commonwealth of Pennsylvania v. Mumia Abu-Jamal|1982 murder trial]] of [[Mumia Abu-Jamal]].<ref name=NYTobit /> Sabo served as a judge from 1974 until his retirement in 1998.<ref name=Phillyobit>{{cite news|last=Pray|first=Rusty|title=Albert F. Sabo, 81, Abu-Jamal trial judge|url=http://articles.philly.com/2002-05-10/news/25347214_1_albert-f-sabo-judge-sabo-s-judge-sabo|work=The Philadelphia Inquirer|date=May 10, 2002|page=B7}}</ref> Born in [[Philadelphia]], Sabo grew up in the [[Northern Liberties, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Northern Liberties]] neighborhood and graduated from [[Roman Catholic High School (Philadelphia)|Roman Catholic High School]] in 1938. He earned two degrees from the [[University of Pennsylvania]]: a bachelor's degree in economics from the [[Wharton School]] in 1942 and a law degree from the [[University of Pennsylvania Law School]] in 1948. Sabo was a [[World War II]] veteran and part of the [[United States Army Air Corps]].<ref name=Phillyobit /> For 15 years while on the bench, Sabo exclusively heard [[homicide]] cases.<ref name=NYTobit /> Sabo presided over 31 cases that resulted in the imposition of the [[Capital punishment in the United States|death penalty]], which was reported in 1992 by ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]'' to be the most in the state.<ref name=NYTobit /> In 1995, in the time before Abu-Jamal was scheduled to be executed, Sabo had 24-hour security due to angry, offensive faxes and calls directed to him.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lounsberry|first=Emilie|title=Abu-jamal Case Puts Focus On Sabo - Again|url=http://articles.philly.com/1995-07-18/news/25676352_1_judge-albert-f-sabo-abu-jamal-case-mumia-abu-jamal|newspaper=The Philadelphia Inquirer|date=July 18, 1995|accessdate=April 22, 2011}}</ref> On September 15, 1995, Sabo denied Abu-Jamal a retrial.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kaufman|first=Marc|title=Sabo Denies Retrial For Abu-jamal|url=http://articles.philly.com/1995-09-16/news/25717413_1_judge-albert-f-sabo-mumia-abu-jamal-abu-jamal-shot-faulkner|accessdate=April 22, 2011|newspaper=The Philadelphia Inquirer|date=September 16, 1995|author2=Quinones Miller, Karen E.|author3=Cass Julia}}</ref> In 2000, the stenographer at the Abu-Jamal trial, Terri Maurer-Carter, signed an affidavit stating that during the trial she overheard the judge saying of the defendant, "Yeah and I'm gonna help 'em fry the nigger."<ref>http://www.philly.com/philly/opinion/inquirer/20111211_Why_freedom_makes_even_more_sense_now_.html</ref> Sabo died in 2002 of [[heart failure]].<ref name=NYTobit>{{cite news | title = Albert F. Sabo, 81, Judge in Murder Trials| work = New York Times| date = May 13, 2002| url = http://www.nytimes.com/2002/05/13/us/albert-f-sabo-81-judge-in-murder-trials.html}}</ref> At the time of his death, he was living in the [[Mount Airy, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Mount Airy]] neighborhood of Philadelphia.<ref name=Phillyobit /> ==References== {{reflist}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Sabo, Albert F. | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = American judge | DATE OF BIRTH = 1920 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 2002 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sabo, Albert F.}} [[Category:1920 births]] [[Category:2002 deaths]] [[Category:Mumia Abu-Jamal]] [[Category:American military personnel of World War II]] [[Category:American Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Pennsylvania state court judges]] [[Category:Deaths from heart failure]] [[Category:People from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] [[Category:United States Army officers]] [[Category:University of Pennsylvania Law School alumni]] [[Category:Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania alumni]] {{US-judge-stub}}
